awd_titl_txt: Unveiling the Obscured Formation of Stars and Galaxies: Large-Scale Legacy Surveys with a New Three Color Imaging Polarimeter on a 50-m Millimeter-Wave Telescope
awd_abstract_narration:
This research program will develop, construct, and deploy a new millimeter-wavelength camera (known as Toltec) for the 50m Large Millimeter Telescope (LMT), located in central Mexico. The main scientific goal is to carry out four major surveys of star formation in the Galaxy and in external galaxies.  The external galaxy survey will include mapping the large scale structure in the universe. Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate students, graduate students, and a postdoc in instrumentation development, a major focus of MSIP.  Enhancing participation, female astronomers will serve as Project Scientist and Deputy Project Scientist for the project. The team will present a series of public outreach activities centered on the science and instrumentation of the project.   

The camera will operate in the three bands 2.1 mm (900 detectors), 1.4mm (1800 detectors), and 1.1mm (3600 detectors), and it will offer the capability of measuring linear polarization.  According to current plans, over the next year the outer two rings of the telescope surface, which cover the area between 32 m and 50 m diameter, will be resurfaced and brought under active control in time for TolTEC to be deployed. Four wide-field legacy surveys are planned: (1) The Clouds-to-Cores Legacy Survey will address questions about the stellar initial mass function;(2)nThe Fields-to-Filaments Legacy Survey will build on recent Herschel space telescope findings of the importance of filaments in star formation and the role of the magnetic field; (3)The Ultra-Deep Survey of Star-forming Galaxies will be a confusion-limited survey of the luminous infrared galaxy population over redshifts 2-10; and (4) The Large Scale Structure Survey will use the Sunyeav Zel'dovich effect to study galaxy cluster formation and dynamics at high redshifts.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for TolTEC (NSF Award No.: 1636621)

The TolTEC project, supported by the National Science Foundation, represents a significant advancement in millimeter-wavelength astronomy. Our team developed and deployed TolTEC, a state-of-the-art, three-band imaging polarimeter installed on the Large Millimeter Telescope (LMT). Designed to address fundamental questions about star and galaxy formation, the project highlights how technology can unlock new insights into our Universe.

Intellectual Merit

TolTEC’s innovative design includes over 7500 kinetic inductance detectors (KIDs), operating across three wavelength bands (1.1 mm, 1.4 mm, and 2.0 mm). This camera incorporates polarization-sensitive detectors and a continuously rotating half-wave plate (CRHWP) to enable precise polarimetric measurements. By integrating advanced optics and cutting-edge cryogenic systems, TolTEC promises unprecedented mapping speeds at millimeter wavelengths with 5-10 arc-second resolution, enabling it to map faint astrophysical structures with high fidelity.

Despite challenges, such as delays from the COVID-19 pandemic and technical hurdles, the project achieved key milestones:

  • First Light: TolTEC achieved first light in June 2022, capturing high-quality images of targets such as the Crab Nebula and the Monoceros R2 star-forming region.
  • Polarimetry: TolTEC’s polarimetric capabilities were validated with observations of the quasar 3c286, demonstrating consistency with prior published results.
  • Data Pipeline: The development of a sophisticated data reduction pipeline, “citlali,” ensures the production of high-quality maps and supports public access to data products via the LMT Dataverse.

Broader Impacts

TolTEC has made significant contributions to workforce development and community engagement:

  • Training: The project provided hands-on training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, resulting in six Ph.D. and two M.Sc. theses. Students gained expertise in instrumentation, data analysis, and observational astronomy.
  • Legacy Science: While the planned surveys have been delayed, TolTEC established the infrastructure necessary to conduct transformative legacy science. Its data products will benefit both the U.S. and international astronomy communities.

In summary, the TolTEC project has successfully demonstrated the potential of advanced polarimetric instrumentation to address critical scientific questions. By combining technological innovation, workforce training, and community engagement, TolTEC exemplifies the transformative impact of sustained investment in astronomical research.
